articles.headline: In Retreat, Bank of America Cancels Debit Card Fee
articles.snippet: The decision came after three competitors said they were backing away from their plans to levy similar charges.
articles.abstract: The decision came after three competitors said they were backing away from their plans to levy similar charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America blinked on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Donors Weigh the Ideals of Meaningful Giving
articles.snippet: While many Americans have always given generously, many wealthy people and foundations donate to art museums, hospital wings or political causes.
articles.abstract: While many Americans have always given generously, many wealthy people and foundations donate to art museums, hospital wings or political causes.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR 11 nights last month, several dozen homeless people slept on plastic sheeting and soiled blankets outside the gleaming new $500 million headquarters of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Seattle. Their objective was a $30,000 grant to help reopen shelters that had been closed by cuts in government funds.

articles.headline: Somalia’s Agony Tests Limits of Aid
articles.snippet: Drought, famine and the anti-Western policies of the Shabab, a militant faction, hinder efforts to feed and clothe hundreds of thousands of refugees, many of them children.
articles.abstract: Drought, famine and the anti-Western policies of the Shabab, a militant faction, hinder efforts to feed and clothe hundreds of thousands of refugees, many of them children.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENADIR HOSPITAL is a chunky block of a building in downtown Mogadishu, built in the 1970s by the Chinese. It has cracked windows, ceiling fans that don’t turn and long, ghostly hallways that stink of human excrement and diesel fuel — all that the nurses have to wash the floors. Each morning, legions of starving people trudge in, the victims of Somalia’s spreading famine. Many have journeyed from hundreds of miles away. They spent every last dollar and every last calorie to make it here, and when they arrive, they simply collapse on the floor. Benadir’s few doctors and nurses are all volunteers and all exhausted, and many wear tattered, bloodied smocks. The minute I walked in, I had a bad feeling I would find what I was looking for.

articles.headline: Whispers of Return to Drachma Grow Louder in Greek Crisis
articles.snippet: A vocal minority in Greece that has long called for a return to the drachma might find itself with a growing group of listeners.
articles.abstract: A vocal minority in Greece that has long called for a return to the drachma might find itself with a growing group of listeners.
articles.lead_paragraph: The political upheaval in Athens has suddenly made the once unspeakable — Greek debt default — a distinct possibility.

articles.headline: Catching a Wave, and Measuring It
articles.snippet: A California company is working to network a fleet of oceangoing robots to measure the data of the sea.
articles.abstract: A California company is working to network a fleet of oceangoing robots to measure the data of the sea.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — James Gosling wants to network the world’s oceans.

articles.headline: Cain Accuser Got a Year’s Salary in Severance Pay
articles.snippet: The National Restaurant Association gave $35,000 in severance pay to a female staff member in the late 1990s after an encounter with Herman Cain, people with knowledge of the payment said on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: The National Restaurant Association gave $35,000 in severance pay to a female staff member in the late 1990s after an encounter with Herman Cain, people with knowledge of the payment said on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Restaurant Association gave $35,000 — a year’s salary — in severance pay to a female staff member in the late 1990s after an encounter with Herman Cain, its chief executive at the time, made her uncomfortable working there, three people with direct knowledge of the payment said on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Jeff Zeleny and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Austerity Faces Test as Greeks Question Their Ties to Euro
articles.snippet: The euro crisis has finally touched real politics, with the Greeks now questioning whether their commitment to Europe and its currency matters more than control over their own future.
articles.abstract: The euro crisis has finally touched real politics, with the Greeks now questioning whether their commitment to Europe and its currency matters more than control over their own future.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The crisis of the euro zone has finally hit the potholed road of real politics, with the Greeks now openly questioning whether their commitment to Europe and its single currency still matters more to them than control over their own future and economic well-being.
